snippet: The suicide rate among middle-age Americans rose 30 percent from 1999 to 2010, with more people now dying of suicide than in car accidents.
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that suicide rate among middle-age Americans rose 30 percent from 1999 to 2010, with more people now dying of suicide than in car accidents; findings prompt concern that generation of baby boomers who have faced years of economic worry and easy access to prescription painkillers may be particularly vulnerable to self-inflicted harm.
lead_paragraph: The suicide rate among middle-age Americans rose 30 percent from 1999 to 2010, with more people now dying of suicide than in car accidents.

headline.seo: Suicide Rate Rises Sharply in U.S.
headline.main: Suicide Rates Rise Sharply in U.S.
headline.print_headline: Suicide Rates In Middle Age Soared in U.S.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
